subject: Critical Thinking
title: Appeal to Nature: Natural Doesn't Mean Good
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Appeal to Nature: Natural Doesn't Mean Good.

hook.text: 'It's natural, so it must be good for you.' Arsenic is natural. So are earthquakes, cancer, and poison ivy.

buildup.text: Appeal to nature: arguing that something is good because it's natural, or bad because it's artificial.

discovery.text: David Hume identified the is-ought problem: you can't derive what SHOULD be from what IS in nature.

twist.text: The $200 billion 'natural products' industry is built on this fallacy.

climax.text: Nature is indifferent to human welfare. Whether something is good requires evidence of outcomes, not origin.

punchline.text: Natural or not, show me the evidence.

quiz.question: Why is the appeal to nature a fallacy?
options: Being natural doesn't determine whether something is good or bad
